title: Bagaimana Katadata menganalisis preferensi pendengar Indonesia di Spotify?
description: Katadata mengumpulkan lagu-lagu yang paling sering diputar di Spotify dan daftar putar yang berkaitan dengan genre populer utama, termasuk dangdut
contents:
Contents
Data
Valensi
Daftar putar Lagu
Teratas
Lagu-lagu genre populer
utama
Penutup
Referensi

Pada hari Senin, 23 Mei 2022, Katadata menerbitkan artikel yang menganalisis preferensi pendengar
Indonesia dan mood lagu-lagu dengan genre populer utama. Kami
mengumpulkan data dari platform pemutar audio Spotify.
Tulisan ini akan menjelaskan proses, asumsi dan keputusan-keputusan
di balik analisis tersebut. Lebih penting lagi, tulisan ini juga
membahas keterbatasan dari analisis ini dan bagaimana menerjemahkan
datanya dengan mempertimbangkan keterbatasan tersebut.
Saya tidak akan membahas sisi teknis dari analisis tersebut secara
mendetail di sini. Namun, anda bisa cek kode dan data yang kami gunakan
untuk menulis artikel tersebut di repository GitHub ini.
Data
Kami menggunakan dua himpunan data. Pertama, kami mengumpulkan
lagu-lagu yang paling sering diputar. Untuk data ini, kami menggunakan
daftar putar Lagu Teratas yang tersedia untuk 58 negara dan daerah di
Spotify, termasuk Indonesia. Daftar putar ini, yang diperbarui setiap
minggu, berisi 50 lagu.
Set data ini memberikan kami 2.900 lagu secara keseluruhan. Daftar
putar yang kami gunakan ini terakhir diperbarui pada 13 Mei 2022.
Lagu-lagu tersebut tidak unik. Walaupun proses pembersihan data pada
umumnya menyingkirkan duplikat, kami membiarkannya karena pendengar di
Indonesia dan Afrika Selatan mungkin sering memutar lagu yang sama. Lagu
“As It Was” dari Harry Styles, misalnya, muncul di 55 daftar putar Lagu
Teratas.
Kedua, kami menggunakan fasilitas pencarian di Spotify untuk
mengumpulkan lagu-lagu sekaligus mengelompokkannya secara longgar
menurut genre. Kami menggunakan masing-masing genre sebagai kata kunci.
Kemudian kami mengarahkan pencariannya ke daftar putar yang berkaitan
dengan genre tersebut, baik yang dikurasi oleh Spotify ataupun
pengguna.
Ada beberapa pengaturan yang penting terkait pencariannya. Pertama,
kami hanya mengumpulkan lagu-lagu (dari berbagai musisi di berbagai
negara) yang tersedia di pasar Indonesia. Kedua, kami membatasi hasil
pencariannya ke 50 daftar lagu yang pertama muncul untuk masing-masing
genre. Ketiga, kami hanya mengumpulkan 100 lagu pertama dari setiap
daftar putar.
Tentu, tidak semua pencarian memberikan persis 50 daftar putar dan
tidak semua daftar putar memiliki 100 lagu, apalagi lebih.
Kami menggunakan artikel Wikipedia soal genre untuk memperoleh daftar
genre populer utama. Berdasarkan daftar tersebut, kami memilih sembilan
yang relatif lebih relevan untuk konteks analisis kami, yaitu
elektronik, hip hop, jazz, pop, punk, reggae, rock, metal dan R&B.
Lalu kami menambahkan dangdut, karena… siapa yang bisa bilang tidak ke
lagu-lagu Didi Kempot?
Set data ini memberikan kami 30.169 lagu. Lagi-lagi, kami membiarkan
duplikat antargenre karena satu lagu bisa dianggap cocok dengan lebih
dari satu genre.
Namun, kami perlu menghapus beberapa lagu. Pertama, lagu yang tidak
memiliki nilai untuk valensi, sebuah karakteristik audio yang kami
perlukan untuk analisis. Kedua, lagu-lagu yang berdurasi lebih dari 10
menit. Ketiga, lagu-lagu yang memiliki karakteristik mirip dengan gelar
wicara, buku yang dibacakan (audiobook) atau puisi. Proses
pembersihan ini menyisakan kami dengan 30.013 lagu.

Valensi
Kami tertarik untuk mengetahui preferensi pendengar Indonesia
berdasarkan mood lagu. Untuk itu, kami menggunakan valensi.
Spotify menyusun ukuran persepsi ini untuk menggambarkan “kepositifan
musik” sebuah lagu dengan skala antara 0 dan 1. Algoritme ini dilatih
berdasarkan peringkat kepositifan lagu oleh para ahli, menurut media
mingguan The Economist.
Lagu dengan valensi yang tinggi terdengar lebih positif, misalnya
bahagia, ceria atau antusias. Sebaliknya, lagu dengan valensi yang
rendah terdengar lebih negatif, misalnya sedih, murung atau marah.
Namun, tidak semua lagu dengan lirik yang murung memiliki valensi
yang rendah, seperti lagu “Hati-Hati di Jalan” oleh Tulus.
Ada dua variabel lain yang relevan untuk memahami ini. Pertama,
danceability, yang menggambarkan seberapa cocok sebuah lagu
untuk berdansa atau menari dalam skala antara 0 dan 1 menurut “tempo,
stabilitas ritme, kekuatan ketukan dan keteraturan keseluruhan.” Kedua,
energi, sebuah ukuran persepsi terkait intensitas dan aktivitas dengan
skala yang sama. Lagu yang energik biasanya terdengar cepat, keras dan
berisik.
Valensi memiliki korelasi positif dengan danceability dan
energi. Lagu “Hati-Hati di Jalan” memiliki danceability dan
energi yang lumayan tinggi, yaitu masing-masing 0,64 dan 0,43.



Walaupun mencerminkan mood lagu, valensi
belum tentu mewakili kebahagiaan pendengar. Bagi
sebagian orang, suasana hati menentukan lagu yang mereka pilih.
Kadang-kadang, saya juga begitu. Tapi lagu yang sering saya putar
belum tentu mencerminkan suasana hati saya. Saya lumayan sering memutar
lagu “Both Sides Now” dari Joni Mitchell. Lagu ini mendapat valensi
serendah 0,26. Tapi bukan berarti saya sering murung. (Atau iya? 🤔)
Daftar putar Lagu Teratas
Daftar putar Lagu Teratas Indonesia memperoleh 34.594 suka per 22 Mei
2022; Lagu Teratas Global memperoleh 767.121 suka pada waktu yang sama.
Walaupun jumlah suka ini (dan jumlah pemutaran lagu-lagunya) belum tentu
mewakili selera semua pengguna Spotify, daftar putar ini cukup baik
untuk memperkirakan preferensi pendengar pada umumnya.
Namun, daftar putar ini hanya menggambarkan lagu-lagu yang paling
sering diputar dalam periode tertentu, terutama ketika datanya
dikumpulkan.
Dengan demikian, kami tidak bisa menggeneralisasi temuan analisisnya
ke periode lain. Preferensi pendengar di Indonesia pada pertengahan
bulan Mei mungkin berbeda dengan akhir bulan Desember. Lagu-lagu yang
ceria mungkin lebih sering diputar dari biasanya menjelang Natal dan
tahun baru.
The Economist menemukan bahwa terdapat pola musiman dalam
preferensi pendengar di Spotify, berdasarkan analisis terhadap 200 lagu
yang paling sering diputar per hari antara 1 Januari 2017 dan 29 Januari
2020.
Lagu-lagu genre populer
utama
Klasifikasi tidak selalu mudah, mungkin terutama dalam seni seperti
musik. Kami mengelompokkan lagu-lagu berdasarkan daftar putar yang
berkaitan dengan masing-masing genre menggunakan fasilitas pencarian
Spotify. Tentu, seharusnya ada cara yang lebih teliti dari ini.
Kami tidak ingin mengklaim bahwa sampel kami representatif. Kami
tidak mencakup semua genre populer utama, seperti country,
latin atau funk. Kami juga tidak melakukan klasifikasi berdasarkan genre
turunan atau yang berkaitan. Untuk konteks Indonesia, kami tidak
memasukkan genre yang berkaitan dengan wilayah atau etnis tertentu,
seperti lagu Batak.
Daftar putar yang kami kumpulkan sebagian dikurasi oleh pengguna,
sehingga selera dan pengetahuan mereka menentukan lagu apa saja yang
masuk ke dalam daftar putarnya. Sementara itu, tidak semua pengguna
(termasuk saya) memiliki keahlian dalam musik, apalagi menentukan genre
sebuah lagu.
Jumlah hasil pencarian terhadap daftar putar (dan lagu-lagu di
dalamnya) juga menentukan kualitas set datanya. Semakin banyak daftar
putar yang dikumpulkan, semakin besar kemungkinan menemukan lagu yang
mungkin terdengar tidak cocok dikelompokkan dalam genre tertentu.
Misalnya, lagu “Pelangi” dari HiVi! masuk ke salah satu daftar putar
yang muncul dalam pencarian dengan kata kunci “jazz” di Spotify.
Dengan banyaknya lagu yang memiliki ciri-ciri yang cocok dengan lebih
dari satu genre, tidak mudah untuk menentukan apakah sebuah lagu relevan
untuk genre tertentu dalam skala yang besar, apalagi memisahkan mana
yang salah diklasifikasi.
Beberapa genre mungkin memiliki ciri khas yang mudah dikenali,
seperti rap. Lagu-lagunya bisa dikenali dengan salah satu karakteristik
audio yang disediakan oleh Spotify, yaitu speechiness.
Terakhir, kami berusaha untuk memperkirakan tren mood lagu
masing-masing genre dengan rata-rata valensi. Namun, data agregasi
seperti ini hanya satu bagian dari gambar yang lebih besar. Dalam jazz
yang cenderung terdengar murung menurut rata-rata valensinya, ada
lagu-lagu seperti “Mati Saja” dari Barry Likumahuwa yang terdengar
positif menurut Spotify.



Penutup
Terlepas dari semua ini, saya hanya berharap artikelnya memberikan
jeda yang menghibur dari berita-berita serius.
Referensi
Exploring the Spotify API with R: A tutorial for
beginners, by a beginner oleh Mia Smith
Understanding + classifying genres using Spotify audio
features oleh Kaylin Pavlik
Data from Spotify suggest that listeners are gloomiest
in February oleh The Economist
Cek juga #TidyTuesday

title: My data-driven stories on The Jakarta Post
description: A recap of my data journalism at The Jakarta Post between 2021 and 2022. From the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on wages to the decline in homeownership
contents:
Do you know that The Jakarta Post (JakPost) has been publishing
data-driven stories? JakPost did not have a data journalism desk or
section on the website and the newspaper. But my colleagues and I had
been wrangling data to find stories.
This post compiles the data visualizations from my 14 selected
stories between mid-2021 and March 2022. Since there was no data
journalism desk, I worked on these stories with the business desk. So my
stories are largely related to the impact of COVID-19 on
livelihoods.
When working on these stories, I was still learning and trying to
figure out some stuff. (Actually, I still do.) Writing this post,
therefore, has allowed me to not just look back at what I’ve achieved,
but also see what I could have done better. As a result, I recreated the
charts and map with a couple improvements where necessary.
You can find the code and data behind these visualizations in this GitHub
repository. The repo also tells you the changes I’ve made to
them.
Enjoy!
Indonesia
remains Java-centric despite Jokowi’s infrastructure campaign
May 23, 2021
Read the story on this
link.
The first chart in this story shows that population and economic
development had remained too concentrated in Java between 1971 and
2020.



The second chart shows that provinces with a higher per capita income
tended to have more incoming lifetime migrants relative to their
population.



The following map shows that lifetime migrants also tended to choose
neighboring provinces or the ones closest to their home.



COVID-19 takes severe toll
on wages
June 14, 2021
Read the story on this
link.
The first chart in this story shows that the average net wage in real
terms declined in August 2020 from a year earlier, while the
unemployment rate rose sharply to a level not seen at least in the past
four years.



The second chart shows that sectors that fared better, such as
information and communication, recorded a smaller decline in its real
wage. Meanwhile, hard-hit sectors like transportation and storage
recorded a steeper decline in its real wage.



The next chart shows that while the average net wage in the majority
of provinces stayed above the minimum wage in nominal terms, it fell to
a level below the floor in Jakarta or even further below the floor in
some provinces, such as West Sulawesi.



Indonesian
homeownership slides as affordability issues arise
June 28, 2021
Read the story on this
link.
The first chart in this story shows that homeownership slightly fell
between 1999 and 2020 in general. Bali and Jakarta recorded a
significant decline, while Bengkulu and Jambi recorded a small increase
in homeownership.



The next chart shows that house prices had been growing at a slower
pace at least since 2014. In Bandar Lampung, Lampung, house prices
declined during the pandemic.



The next chart shows that the average monthly mortgage payment in
Jakarta and Yogyakarta was unusually high in 2019, given the mortgage
terms.



Factory imports show
recovery uncertainty
July 1, 2021
Read the story on this
link.
This chart shows that imports of raw materials and capital goods had
not shown a promising sign of recovery as of April 2021. While imports
of raw materials continued to pick up pace, imports of capital goods did
not.



Wealth
gap narrows in Indonesia as stock market slumps, house prices grow
July 12, 2021
Read the story on this
link.
The first chart in this story shows the estimated wealth distribution
in Indonesia between 2019 and 2020. As the share of wealth of the bottom
40 percent slightly expanded while that of the richest 10 percent
shrank, the wealth gap was estimated to narrow.



The second chart shows that wealth per adult in Indonesia continued
to grow despite at a slower pace during the pandemic. The growth hinged
largely on nonfinancial assets like houses.



Slow
vaccination takes toll on Indonesia in uneven global recovery
August 1, 2021
Read the story on this
link.
The first chart in this story shows that the International Monetary
Fund (IMF) revised downward the 2021 economic growth forecast for
Indonesia in its July outlook from the previous one. Indonesia joined
other countries with a downward revision, such as India and neighboring
Malaysia.



The second chart shows that Indonesia, like other low and
lower-middle income countries, was falling behind its richer peers in
inoculating its citizens against COVID-19. This trend is associated with
the growth outlook.



Emergency
curbs reverse recovery in consumer confidence, retail sales
August 12, 2021
Read the story on this
link.
The first chart in this story shows that the Delta wave, which peaked
in July 2021, interrupted the recovery in consumer confidence and retail
sales. The consumer confidence index fell back to a level nearly as
pessimistic as in October 2020. The retail sales index also contracted
again compared with a year earlier.



The next chart shows that visitors to retail and recreation places
started declining in June, even before the government tightened mobility
restrictions as cases surged, especially in Java and Bali.



Indonesia
lags behind in decoupling economic and emission growth
September 5, 2021
Read the story on this
link.
The first chart in this story shows that Indonesia had not been able
to grow its economy without slowing down both production and
consumption-based CO2 emissions between 1990 and 2020. Meanwhile, other
countries had managed to do so. Some countries, such as Singapore,
developed their economy while reducing its emissions.



The following chart shows that Indonesia’s human development index
(HDI) might be below the threshold of high-human development if we
accounted for emission and material footprint.



Majority
of affluent Indonesians plan to retire early
December 11, 2021
Read the story on this
link.
This chart shows that the share of affluent individuals planning to
retire before turning 65 was highest in Indonesia among the surveyed
countries. As a result, the share of these individuals who had not
started saving or investing for retirement was very low in the
country.



Yearender
2021: How the Delta wave disrupted Indonesia’s economic recovery
December 26, 2021
Read the story on this
link.
This chart shows how the Delta wave hit Indonesia when the rate of
vaccination against the virus was still very low. This forced the
government to tighten mobility restrictions. As a result, the country
recorded a slower economic growth in the July to September period in
2021 than the previous quarter.



How
China beats US as trade, investment partner for Indonesia
January 4, 2022
Read the story on this
link.
The first chart in this story shows that the share of Indonesia’s
exports to and imports from China started growing in early 2000s,
following the latter’s accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
By late 2000s, the share of trade with China was larger than that with
the United States (US).



The next chart shows that net foreign direct investment (FDI) flow
from China to Indonesia largely remained positive between 2010 and 2020.
Meanwhile, the flow from the US showed a downward trend in general.



Domestic
travelers ‘not enough’ to revive Bali tourism
January 18, 2022
Read the story on this
link.
This chart shows the large share of foreign guests at star-rated and
other hotels in Bali in 2019. As a popular international tourist
destination, the province was heavily dependent on foreign tourists.



COVID-19
expedites deindustrialization in Indonesia
February 9, 2022
Read the story on this
link.
This chart shows the premature deindustrialization that started
taking place in Indonesia in mid-2000s, as suggested by the share of
manufacturing value added in real gross domestic product (GDP), and how
the pandemic worsened it.



COVID-19
pulls more workers into low-paying service sector jobs
March 5, 2022
Read the story on this
link.
This chart shows that most Indonesian workers in services had less
than a college educational attainment in 2021. These workers were
concentrated in traditional and low-paying sectors, such as
accommodation and food service activities, transportation and storage,
and wholesale and retail trade.

title: My dataviz in 2020
description: One scatter plot, one animated scatter plot, one map and one table on industrial park, COVID-19 and well-being
contents:
I created dozens of data visualizations on various topics in 2020
both for work and personal projects. From COVID-19 to industrial
park.
I published my first “data-driven story” on poverty in Jakarta on The
Jakarta Post in February last year. Aside from analyzing data and
creating visualizations for work, I also do it outside work, mostly for
learning. I usually publish the result on my Twitter account.
Here’s my favorite data visualizations from last year, with a few
improvements.






Twitter

June 20, 2020







The Jakarta Post

July 17, 2020







Twitter

July 19, 2020










Twitter

Sep. 9, 2020





Show code

# Packages ----

library(tidyverse)
library(gapminder)
library(gganimate)


# Data ----

asean5 <- c("Singapore", "Philippines", "Thailand", "Malaysia")

gapminderGrouped <- gapminder %>% 
  mutate(
    pop = pop / 1000000,
    group = case_when(
      country == "Indonesia" ~ "Indonesia",
      country %in% asean5 ~ "ASEAN-5",
      TRUE ~ "Rest of the world"
    )
  )


# Chart ----

colorPrimary <- "#757575"
colorPrimaryLight <- "#E0E0E0"

axisBreakX <- c(100, 1000, 10000, 100000, 1000000)

plotGapminder <- ggplot(
  data = gapminderGrouped, 
  mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp)
) +
  geom_point(
    mapping = aes(fill = group, size = pop),
    pch = 21, 
    color = "white", 
    alpha = 0.85
  ) +
  scale_x_log10(
    breaks = axisBreakX,
    labels = format(axisBreakX, scientific = FALSE, big.mark = ","),
    limits = c(100, 1000000)
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    breaks = seq(0, 100, 20),
    limits = c(0, 100),
    expand = c(0, 0),
    position = "right"
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Indonesia" = "#2477B3",
      "ASEAN-5" = "#55CBF2",
      "Rest of the world" = "#BDBDBD"
    )
  ) +
  scale_size_binned(
    name = "Population (in millons)",
    breaks = seq(0, 1500, 300),
    limits = c(0, 1500),
    labels = format(seq(0, 1500, 300), scientific = FALSE, big.mark = ",")
  ) +
  guides(
    fill = guide_legend(
      title = NULL, 
      label.position = "left",
      label.hjust = 1,
      override.aes = list(size = 2.5)
    ),
    size = guide_bins(
      title.position = "top",
      title.hjust = 1,
      label.theme = element_text(size = 6.6, color = colorPrimary),
      direction = "horizontal",
      override.aes = list(fill = "#BDBDBD")
    )
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Getting better, but not enough",
    subtitle = paste0(
      "Life expectancy (in years) and GDP per capita (in international ",
      "dollars in 2005 prices)\nYear: {frame_time}"    
    ),
    x = "GDP per capita\n(in log scale)",
    y = "Life expectancy",
    caption = "Chart: Dzulfiqar Fathur Rahman | Source: Gapminder"
  ) +
  theme(
    text = element_text(size = 12, color = colorPrimary),
    axis.title = element_text(size = rel(0.75)),
    axis.text = element_text(size = rel(0.75), color = colorPrimary),
    axis.line.x = element_line(color = "black"),
    axis.ticks.x = element_line(color = "black"),
    axis.ticks.y = element_blank(),
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "#FFFFFF"),
    panel.grid.major.x  = element_line(color = colorPrimaryLight),
    panel.grid.major.y = element_line(color = colorPrimaryLight),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_text(
      face = "bold", 
      size = rel(1),
      color = "black", 
      margin = margin(b = 5)
    ),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(
      size = rel(0.75), 
      color = colorPrimary, 
      margin = margin(b = 5)
    ),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    plot.caption = element_text(
      size = rel(0.7),
      color = "#9E9E9E",
      hjust = 0,
      margin = margin(t = 5)
    ),
    plot.caption.position = "plot",
    legend.margin = margin(0, unit = "mm"),
    legend.title = element_text(size = rel(0.7)),
    legend.text = element_text(size = rel(0.7)),
    legend.key = element_blank(),
    legend.key.height = unit(0.35, "mm"),
    legend.position = c(0.75, 0.4),
    legend.justification = "left",
    plot.margin = margin(0, unit = "mm")
  )

plotGapminderAnimated <- plotGapminder +
  transition_time(year) +
  ease_aes()

anim_save(
  "life-expectancy-income-per-cap.gif",
  animation = plotGapminderAnimated,
  width = 6,
  height = 3.708,
  units = "in",
  res = 150
)
